sn8.1:1.2: This chapter features the poetry of Vaṅgīsa, the finest poet of the Sangha, providing a prose setting for his Theragāthā verses at Thag 21.1. There are notable differences between the two versions. In several passages, including this one, he reflects on the struggles he faced in his path, showing a high degree of self-awareness and persistence.
sn8.1:1.4: Period art depicts women as bare-breasted and draped in elaborate jewellery.
sn8.1:1.5: “Dissatisfaction” (anabhirati) with his life of seclusion and celibacy.
sn8.1:3.1: There is some confusion regarding the Pali ugga (“warrior chief”). Pali commentaries and Sanskrit sources (Manu 10.9) speak of a caste called ugga (Sanskrit ugra), born of a khattiya father and a sudda mother. They were reviled as cruel, and their duty was to catch snakes and other underground vermin (Manu 10.49). This is not the aristocratic warriors referred to here. The distinction is noted in Medhātithi’s commentary to Manu 4.212, who says the Vedic ugra was a key figure in the king’s alliance, which is supported by the use at DN 3:2.7.2.
